Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: This morning, I was sipping coffee when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, an old acquaintance from college. He sounded desperate—his moving help had bailed, and he needed someone to help carry boxes to his new apartment. I could hear the stress in his voice, and I knew he didn’t have many people to call. As an acquaintance, I felt I should step up, offer my help, and not let him down. But today is also election day, and I’d planned to vote before work. I’d set aside my passport as ID, but now, with Mark’s request, I’d have to rush, and I might forget my ID or bring the wrong one. I could always fetch another ID later, but the polling station is out of the way, and I worry about lines growing longer as the day goes on. I feel torn—Mark is counting on me, but so is my civic duty. The pressure of being a reliable acquaintance clashes with my responsibility as a voter, and I can’t shake the anxiety of letting someone—or something—down.
